Key Laboratory of Ecophysics and Department of Physics College of Science Shihezi University North fourth Road Shihezi 832003 PR China Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) can efficiently and selectively reduce carbon dioxide into chemical fuel. Here, we designed the novel catalysts of transition-metal atoms anchored on Janus WSSe basal plane (TM@SSe) monolayer by first-principles calculations. The results show that Zn@WSSe has the best CO2RR catalytic activity with limit potential of -0.32 V and a high selectivity for the competitive hydrogen precipitation reaction (HER). Moreover, ab initio molecular dynamics simulation (AIMD) calculation at 300 K indicated high thermodynamic stability of Zn@WSSe. The study of the rate limiting step (CO*+H++e−→ *CHO) of the Zn@WSSe structure illustrates that the CO2RR catalytic activity of these candidate catalysts largely depends on the better interaction between Zn atoms and surrounding W atoms, which H atom is more easily adsorbed to C atom, making the reaction process easier to achieve. The above research provides a new way to design efficient CO2RR electrocatalyst under ambient conditions. Graphical abstract The electrocatalytic performance of the transition metal (3d 4d and 5d) embedd-ed in WSSe monolayer for CO2RR is investigated by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The results indicate that Zn@WSSe possesses the best catalytic performance with remarkably low rate-limiting step of 0.32 eV toward CO2 product. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction High catalytic activity DFT calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the rapid development of economy, the emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2) are increasing as energy use and industrial activities [1]. The rapid increase of CO2 concentration in environmental seriously affects human lives and thus it is a major problem to reduce the emissions of CO2 for modern society [2]. The traditional methods (adsorption, filtration, etc.) depend on high-energy inputs for high-pressures and temperature [3–5]. The electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) can use electricity to convert CO2 into useful chemicals and fuels, which has a huge potential for CO2 conversion and utilization [6,7]. Compared with other methods, the required reaction conditions of CO2RR are simple, and the reaction can achieve higher energy utilization rate [8]. However, CO2RR still faces many challenges such as competition with hydrogen precipitation reactions, high limiting potentials, poor product selectivity and Faraday efficiency [9]. Therefore, it is greatly significant to search for highly selective and active electrocatalysts for CO2RR. The single-atom catalysts (SACs) usually possess high selectivity toward specific products due to the homogeneity of active sites and thus have been widely applied for various catalytic reaction [10]. In addition, more and more experimental and theoretical found that the SAC for CO2 electrolytic reduction has significantly improved activity and selectivity [11]. Pan and his colleagues found SAC exhibits high selectivity and excellent Faraday efficiency for CO2 reduction products [12]. It is a considerable challenge to obtain high stable and large-scale synthetic single-atom catalyst because metal atoms tend to diffuse and aggregate to form larger particles [13,14]. Therefore, it is urgent to find a new substrate that can avoid metal atom aggregation and anchor single metal atom. To anchor SACs, 2D materials with excellent electrocatalytic properties have been extensively investigated as the base materials for catalysts [15–19]. Among 2D materials, transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have been widely studied in catalytic fields because of their remarkable electronic properties [20–23]. Salehi-khojin et al. proved experimentally that TMDs can be used as CO2RR catalyst [24]. Nørskov et al. emphasized that TMDs has great potential in CO2RR catalytic performance through density functional theory (DFT) calculation [25]. In recent years, a new 2D TMD material called Janus monolayer has been successfully synthesized by improved chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [26]. Janus 2D materials are expected to improve the catalytic performance of TMDs because of structural asymmetry of TMDs [27]. At present, Janus 2D materials embedded with single transition metal atom are used in a range of SAC reactions [28–31]. For example, Dequan Er predict that it is possible to realize a Janus TMD-based catalyst that can readily provide excellent catalytic performance [32]. Although many transition metal atoms embedded in WSSe have been investigated as electrocatalysts, studies exploring CO2 reduction remain challenging. Here, we investigated transition metal (3d, 4d, and 5d elements) embedded on WSSe nanosheets (TM@WSSe) as CO2RR electrocatalysts by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. According to potential-determinating steps (PDS) of CO2RR, Zn@WSSe possesses the lowest limiting potential with –0.32 V among all studied systems. In addition, HER will also be effectively suppressed throughout the CO2RR process. The study of the rate limiting step (CO* + H + + e − →*CHO) of Zn@WSSe structure shows that the strong interaction between C-H atoms makes the Zn@WSSe structure have the high catalytic performance and low limiting potential. This result may provide a new idea for the study of catalyst based on Zn@WSSe and other frameworks. 2 Computation methods All DFT calculations were completed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [33,34]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA-PBE) exchange-correlation (XC) generalization function was used to describe the XC energy, while the projection-enhanced wave (PAW) method was used to deal with electron-ion interactions [35–37]. The Van Der Waals was used to modify dispersion correction [38], and cut-off energy was set to 450 eV. The convergence energy and force criteria for the relaxation process of the structure were set to 10−4 eV and 0.05 eV/Å, respectively. The WS2 and WSSe model was built by using 4 × 4 × 1 supercells and sampled using the Brillouin zone, where a 2 × 2 × 1 grid centered on the gamma (Γ) point was used for geometrical optimization. To avoid interactions between two adjacent periodic cells, the vacuum layer was set at about 20 Å in the z-direction. In the process of electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction, the change of Gibbs free energy is a very important indicator for evaluating catalytic performance. According to the research, the Gibbs free energy change of reaction pathway is defined as [39]: (1) Δ G = Δ E + E Z P E − T Δ S In this formula, ΔE represents the energy difference before and after each hydrogenation calculated from DFT. Ezpe and ΔS is the change of zero energy and entropy at each step, which can be obtained by calculating the vibration frequency of the adsorbed intermediate on the substrate by DFT. T is the temperature, set to 298.15 K. The most positive in the whole CO2RR process ΔG (ΔGmax) was considered as the rate determination step, and the starting potential (Uonset) can be obtained from the following formula [40] (2) U onest = − Δ G max / e In the first step of the electrocatalytic CO2RR process, the adsorption of CO2 on catalyst was studied. The adsorption energy (Eads) of CO2 and CO2RR intermediates is calculated by the following equation [41] (3) E ads = E su b * − ( E sub + E * ) Where Esub*, Esub and E* are the total energy of the whole system, the energy of the substrate and the energy of the adsorbate, respectively. The binding energy (Eb) of TM@WSSe is described by [41] (4) E b = E T M @ W S S e − E W S S e − E T M where ETM@WSSe, EWSSe, and ETM are total energy of the TM@WSSe, WSSe and single TM atom, respectively. The cohesive energies (Ecoh) of structure is described by [42] (5) E coh = E n T M − n E T M Where EnTM and ETM represent the energy of metal blocks and isolated metal atoms, respectively. n is the number of metal atoms in a metal block. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of TM@WSSe monolayer The catalytic performance of the pristine WSSe are investigated firstly into CO2RR. For pristine WSSe, the exposed S atoms and Se atoms on the WSSe surface may act as active site for CO2 activation as shown in Fig. S1. Our calculation results showed that the C-S and C-Se distances are 3.17 Å, and 3.35 Å, respectively. This indicates that the interaction between CO2 and S/Se atoms is relatively weak, and CO2 molecules cannot be effectively activated. To improve the catalytic activity of pristine WSSe, TM is anchored on WSSe, and TM@WSSe will be focused on in the following discussion. Two typical structures of TM@WSSe were first considered, where the S and Se atoms were replaced by a single TM atom, respectively. The binding energies of the TM atoms on the doped S and Se vacancies (TM@WSvSe and TM@WSSev) were calculated as shown in Fig. 1 . One can find that the Eb of TM@WSvSe is smaller than that of TM@WSSev, indicating that the most TM atoms anchored in S defects have high stability. Therefore, we calculated the TM atoms anchored in S defects of WSSe. To further investigate the stability of metal adsorption on TM@WSSe structures, we calculated the cohesive energies of metals as shown in Fig. S2. We found that the binding energies of most TM@WSSe structures are more negative than the respective cohesive energies of metals, indicating high stability of single atoms embedded on WSSe and avoiding metal aggregation. 3.2 Screening of Zn@WSSe as CO2RR electrocatalysts Excellent electrocatalyst materials are selected according to the following criteria: (1) CO2 molecules have appropriate adsorption energy on the catalyst surface and a TM- CO2 bond that ensures adequate activation of CO2 molecules. (2) The low ΔG of the PDS which means the reduced energy consumption. (3) The selectivity of CO2RR is another index to evaluate the catalytic performance. Stable adsorption of CO2 is the initial step in the CO2RR process and is important for the screening of high performance CO2RR catalysts. The metal center provides a good adsorption site for gas molecules in the TM@WSSe structure. As a result, CO2 and other intermediates will be better adsorbed to the metal atoms on the surface. The adsorption energy and bond length between TM and CO2 molecule are calculated. The results show that all the TM- CO2 bond lengths are less than 2.50 Å, and adsorption energies of TM@WSSe are more than –0.40 eV, indicating a strong interaction between these materials and CO2 molecules, which can provide further activation of CO2 molecules. And these materials may be suitable as potential efficient catalysts for CO2RR. Therefore, we will further screen these catalysts. In order to simply and effectively screen excellent CO2RR electrocatalysts, we considered all the reaction intermediates. During the CO2RR process, stable intermediates will be transformed into unstable intermediate structures and a large amount of energy needs to be introduced to break the stable chemical bonds. The occurrence of positive free energy changes in this process is thermodynamically unfavorable. Study identifies potential rate-limiting step for CO2RR are CO2→*COOH, *CO→*CHO, *CHO→*CHOH and *OH→H2O reactions [43]. The values of ΔGmax of TM@WSSe structures are shown in Table S1, which shows TM@WSSe (TM = Zn, Co, Hf, Os, Ru, Sc, Tc, Y, Zr) has less negative initiation potential. It has been found that Zn@WSSe structures have lowest energy change for the potential rate-limiting step. Therefore, we need to further investigate and discuss for Zn@WSSe structure. In addition to compare the catalytic performance of these SACs more visually, volcano curves were investigated for the relationship between the bond length (transition metals and adsorbed molecule) of rate-limiting step and the limiting potential (Fig. S3), where the position of the volcano peak represents the best catalytic performance. HER is a competing reaction for CO2RR. H + ions in the hydrogenation reaction may adsorb to the active sites on the catalyst surface to form H2 molecules during the reaction, resulting in low Faraday efficiency (FE) and destroying the selectivity of CO2RR [44,45]. In order to clarify the selectivity of the catalyst, the change free energy of production of H +, *COOH and *HCOO were calculated and displayed in Fig. 2 (b). One can see that Zn@WSSe is under the parity line, which indicates high selectivity for CO2RR. Therefore, following the established criteria, Zn@WSSe is probably the most qualified electrocatalyst for the CO2RR. 3.3 The stability of Zn@WSSe The thermodynamic stability of Zn@WSSe was evaluated by the 10 ps long ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation at 300 K. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), during the simulation, the total energy fluctuates in a certain range with time and adsorption configuration, and without obvious distortion or cluster aggregation. Therefore, it can be demonstrated that the Zn@WSSe structure has high thermodynamic stability. Moreover, CO2RR typically occurs in aqueous solutions. Therefore, in order to further evaluate the electrochemical stability of the catalyst structure and the stability of the catalyst in a water environment, solvent model was employed to simulate the effects of aqueous solution. We found that the atomic structure of Zn@WSSe remains intact in water without any noticeable deformation (Fig. S4). Therefore, Zn@WSSe exhibits good electrochemical stability and thermal stability in aqueous solutions. To further investigate the stability of Zn@WSSe, Fig. 1 gives the binding energy. The binding energy of Zn@WSSe nanosheets is −0.53 eV, indicating that Zn can be stably embedded in WSSe nanosheets. In order to better understand the interaction between WSSe and Zn atom, we further studied their electronic properties by calculating their density of states. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the projected density of states (PDOS) reveal that there is significant hybridization between Zn-p, W-d orbitals after transition metal loading, indicating that there is a strong interaction between Zn and WSSe nanosheets. Especially, the high peak near the 0–−5 eV shows that strong interaction between Zn and WSSe nanosheets, which can promote the electrocatalytic reaction after adsorption. According to Bader charge analysis, WSSe structure obtains electrons from the transition metal Zn atom and accumulates positive charges that usually contribute to the adsorption of reactive species. In the Zn@WSSe structure, WSSe plundered 0.25 e − from the anchored Zn atoms. The above analysis showed that the better interaction between Zn atom and substrate can ensure the better stability of Zn@WSSe structure. 3.4 Pathways of CO2 reduction reaction of Zn@WSSe According to previous studies, there are many possible mechanisms for CO2 reduction. In order to select the best reaction pathway for Zn@WSSe from Scheme 1 [45], we performed calculations for all intermediates of the reaction process and screened the best reaction pathway for Zn@WSSe in Fig. 4 . 3.4.1 CO2 adsorption on Zn@WSSe Generally, as the first step in the CO2RR process, CO2 adsorption on Zn@WSSe is significant to achieve high-efficiency CO2RR catalyst. CO2 is stably adsorbed on the Zn@WSSe structure as shown in Fig. 5 (a). The distance between adsorbed CO2 and Zn atom is 2.20 Å and the adsorption energy is −0.49 eV, which indicates CO2 molecule can be stably and spontaneously adsorbed on the Zn@WSSe structure. In addition, we carefully studied the PDOS before and after the adsorption of CO2 molecules on the Zn@WSSe surface. Before the adsorption of CO2 molecules, there was no hybridization between the Zn-d and CO2-p orbitals. However, after the adsorption of CO2 molecule, a significant hybridization peak appears between Zn-d and CO2-p orbitals near the Fermi energy level, which indicates that the strong interaction between adsorbed CO2 and Zn@WSSe surface. In addition, Bader charge analyses are also calculated. The adsorbed CO2 molecule gained 0.10 e − from Zn@WSSe configurations, which further ensures the activation of CO2 molecules and effective CO2RR process. 3.4.2 CO2 to CO and HCOOH CO and HCOOH are important intermediate products in the reduction of CO2. For the production of CO, there is CO2RR pathway: CO2 → COOH → CO, and the initial potential of CO generation is −0.03 V. Moreover, the adsorption energy of CO on Zn is −0.40 eV and stable adsorption can promote the further process of CO2 reduction. In the production process of HCOOH, hydrogenation could proceed at O site of *HCOO and C site of *COOH and thus involves two possible pathways: (i) at the C site to form HCOOH* species (COOH*+H ++e −→HCOOH); (ii) at the O atom to generate HOCOH* species(HCOO*+H ++e −→HOCOH). In our work, both reaction pathways were considered. One generation path is CO2 → *COOH → HCOOH, and the other generation path is CO2 → HCOO* → HCOOH. On the surface of Zn@WSSe structure, the free energy change of HCOOH formation reaches 0.58 eV, which is higher than that of further hydrogenation of CO (0.32 eV). Therefore, the formation performance of HCOOH is poor and tends to be further hydrogenated to form new intermediates. 3.4.3 CO2 to CH3OH CH3OH is important product in CO2RR. In the course of further reduction, the CO intermediate is desorbed from the active site or further hydrogenated to form *CHO or *COH. The desorption energies of CO on Zn@WSSe surface are much higher than the next hydrogenation energy. Therefore, *CO tends to be further hydrogenated rather than separated from the catalyst surface. For the entire hydrogenation process, the reaction free energy barrier (0.32 eV) of the protonation step from CO to CHO is the highest. The reaction from *CO to *CHO is the rate determining step (RDS) for the entire hydrogenation process. The next step is to hydrogenate *CHO to *CH2O. It is a spontaneous reaction with negative free energy change. The following step is *CH2O hydrogenated to *CH2OH and finally reduced to CH3OH. These two steps are spontaneous reactions in which the free energy changes is negative value. 3.4.4 CO2 to CH4 CH4 is the hydrocarbon product in CO2RR. The reduction process of CH4 has the same intermediate products before the *CH2OH protonation step compared to the reaction pathway of CH3OH. The protonation for *CH2OH involves two possible pathways: (i) The *CH2OH hydrogenated to *CH3OH (*CH2OH + H + + e − → *CH3OH).(ii) H2O is produced and leaves the catalyst surface, *CH2 remains on the catalyst surface (*CH2OH + H + +e − → *CH2 + H2O). The further hydrogenation reactions to produce the more stable hydrocarbon *CH3, and finally generated to CH4. In Fig. 4, there is a downward trend in the step diagrams for these two steps, both of which are spontaneous reactions with negative free energy changes. For Zn@WSSe, the speed limiting steps for generating CH4 and CH3OH are the same. And the limiting potential is −0.32 V, which is lower than some previously reported catalysts [46–52], as shown in Table S2. In order to investigate CH3OH and CH4 desorption, Fig. 6 (a) displays the changes of bond lengths between Zn and the nearest C atoms of CH3OH and CH4 products, respectively. The dC-Zn value increases sharply during the production of CH3OH and CH4, indicating that the CH3OH and CH4 molecule can be effectively released during the protonated reduction. Since CO2 electroreduction is typically conducted under aqueous conditions. In order to further explore the influence of solvents on the catalytic behavior of the catalyst. Hence, we performed simulated reactions using a solvation model. A comparison of the model in water, vacuum, and solvent systems reveals certain alterations in the limiting potential and rate-determining steps for CO2 reduction to CH3OH and CH4 (Fig. S5). Compared to the models in water and vacuum, the limiting potential for CO2 reduction process only changed by 0.1 V. Therefore, the solvent effect may be negligible for the current catalyst system. 3.5 Mechanism analysis of catalytic activity on Zn@WSSe The excellent catalytic activity of Zn@WSSe for CO2RR was confirmed by analysing the charge changes during CO2RR on Zn@WSSe. Charge variations among three parts (part1: WSSe substrates with S defects; part2: Zn and its surrounding S atoms; part3: adsorbed various molecules) are showed in Fig. 6(b), where the CO2 adsorption is defined as step 0 of charge variations. It was found that the number of charge variations on total reduction process is analogous. Specifically, adsorbed various molecules (part3) gain electrons from Zn@WSSe substrate (part1) via Zn-W group (part2) and have almost unchanged charge throughout hydrogenation process. The Zn atoms remain positively charged in the whole reaction process, which is significant to enhance the adsorption of intermediates [53]. Therefore, the Zn@WSSe substrate can be considered as an electron reservoir, Zn-W group acts as the transmitter for electron transfer, and Zn atom is the active site for CO2RR, and adsorbed species gain electrons to continually proceed the catalytic reaction. To better assess the catalytic activity of Zn@WSSe, the whole hydrogenation processes were investigated for Zn@WSvSe, Zn@WS2, Zn@WSSev and Zn@WSe2. The rate-determining steps of Zn@WSvSe, Zn@WS2, Zn@WSSev and Zn@WSe2 are −0.32 V, −0.35 V, −0.65 V and −0.68 V, respectively, as shown in Table 1 , and this indicates that the Zn@WSSe catalyst is the most efficient one among all the structures. The protonation step from *CO to *CHO is the rate-limiting step for Zn@WS2 and Zn@WSSe in the whole hydrogenation process. To explore the mechanism of rate-limiting step of CO2RR for Zn@WSSe, we studied the interaction between Zn and surrounding atoms and the interaction between Zn and C atom. As shown in Fig. 7 , for Zn@WS2, the distances between Zn and the surrounding W atoms are 2.67 Å, 2.66 Å and 2.68 Å, respectively, while for Zn@WSSe, the distances between Zn and the surrounding atoms are 2.66 Å, 2.65 Å and 2.64 Å, respectively. Compared with Zn@WS2, the strong interaction between Zn and W in Zn@WSSe weakens the interaction between Zn and the adsorbed C atom as shown in Fig. S5, resulting in more easily adsorption of H atom by C atom. To further explore the interaction between Zn and W, Fig. 7(c) and (d) give the PDOS of Zn@WSSe and Zn@WS2, respectively. The strong hybridization between Zn-d state and W-d state indicates that Zn and the surrounding W atoms have strong interactions for Zn@WSSe than that of Zn@WS2. This also leads to a relative weak interaction between Zn atoms and C atoms in the catalyst structure. As a result, the ability of C atoms to adsorb H atoms becomes strong, making the process of adding H easier and reducing the reaction energy barrier, which enhances the catalytic performance. In order to further study the electronic properties of the catalyst structure, the band structures of the two catalysts were studied, as shown in Fig. S6. Zn@WSSe and Zn@WS2 both possesses a direct bandgap with value of 1.25 eV and 1.33 eV, respectively. The lower band gap results in a stronger electron transfer capacity between Zn@WSSe, thus guaranteeing electron transfer efficiency and greatly facilitating electrocatalysis in the CO2RR process. According to the Bader charge analysis, the transferred charges of C atoms from Zn@WSe (0.10 e −) is smaller than that of Zn@WS2 (0.16 e −) which suggests that the Zn@WSe structure has relatively weak interaction with C atom. To further investigate the interaction between Zn and C, Fig. 8 (a), (b) displays the PDOS of Zn and C of Zn@WSSe and Zn@WS2, respectively. We can see that there is more obvious overlap between the upper Zn-d orbital and C-p orbital for Zn@WS2, especially near −5 eV ∼ −10 eV. This indicates that there is weak interaction between Zn@WSSe structure and C atom. This also leads to the fact that further adsorption of H atoms by C atoms on the Zn@WSe surface becomes easier, while the reaction proceeds more difficult on the Zn@WS2 surface, the higher the corresponding limit potential. The interactions between C-H are further verified by the density of state in Fig. 8(c) and (d). The coupling between the p orbital of the C atom and the s orbital of the H atom is significantly stronger for Zn@WSSe than that of Zn@WS2, indicating a strong interaction between the H and C atoms for Zn@WSSe. Therefore, the Zn@WSSe structure is easier to hydrogenation reactions to produce CHO (*CO + H + +e −→*CHO). To further explored the physical mechanisms involved in the reduction process by Bader charge analysis, the lost charges of H atoms for Zn@WS2 and Zn@WSSe are 0.025 e − and 0.022 e −, respectively, which further indicates that H atom and C atom have a strong interaction in Zn@WSSe. The above analysis of PDOS, charge transfer and bond lengths show that the Zn@WSSe structure has the lowest energy barrier from *CO to *CHO. This also results in the lowest starting potential for Zn@WSSe during the reaction. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have systematically investigated a series of TM atoms embedded in WSSe nanosheets as highly efficient CO2RR electrocatalysts based on DFT calculations. The results show that Zn@WSSe displays the most promising catalytic activity with an extremely low limiting potential of −0.32 V for the reduction to CH3OH and CH4, as well as excellent CO2RR selectivity. In addition, the negative binding energy and AIMD simulations demonstrate that Zn@WSSe has high kinetic and thermodynamic stability. Finally, we have gained insight into the origins of such outstanding catalytic performance of Zn@WSSe by detailed study on the rate-limiting steps (*CO → *CHO). The DOS calculations and electronic property analysis indicate that the ultra-low onset potential is due to the strongest interaction between the H and C atoms. The protonation process for C atom is most easily achieved, which means the energy barrier for CHO formation on the Zn@WSSe is lowest. The results of this work can further help experimental and theoretical research in the field of CO2RR. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) can efficiently and selectively reduce carbon dioxide into chemical fuel. Here, we designed the novel catalysts of transition-metal atoms anchored on Janus WSSe basal plane (TM@SSe) monolayer by first-principles calculations. The results show that Zn@WSSe has the best CO2RR catalytic activity with limit potential of -0.32 V and a high selectivity for the competitive hydrogen precipitation reaction (HER). Moreover, ab initio molecular dynamics simulation (AIMD) calculation at 300 K indicated high thermodynamic stability of Zn@WSSe. The study of the rate limiting step (CO*+H++e−→ *CHO) of the Zn@WSSe structure illustrates that the CO2RR catalytic activity of these candidate catalysts largely depends on the better interaction between Zn atoms and surrounding W atoms, which H atom is more easily adsorbed to C atom, making the reaction process easier to achieve. The above research provides a new way to design efficient CO2RR electrocatalyst under ambient conditions.
coredata.dc:title: A DFT screening of transition metal single-atom catalyst anchored on Janus WSSe basal plane for highly efficient carbon dioxide reduction reaction
